title: Microsoft’s Cloud Business Is ‘Fuel in the Tank’ for Earnings
text:
Text size

Microsoft stock has charged ahead in 2019, and Wedbush thinks that the rally can continue, thanks to market-share gains for the company’s cloud product, Azure.

The back story. Microsoft stock (ticker: MSFT) is up nearly 37% year to date, compared with a 16.5% gain for the S&P 500 and a 30% rise for the Technology Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLK). The company is a favorite among analysts as it pushes into hardware, raises its dividend and scores well with environmentally and socially conscious investors.

Yet strong momentum in its cloud business has been one of the biggest highlights for Microsoft. The cloud operation has been one of the key contributors to its robust earnings.

What’s new. Microsoft will report results for its fiscal first quarter on Oct. 23. Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives believes that it will be another strong quarter.

He predicts a “solid beat across the board on both the top and bottom line as cloud strength on Azure and Office 365 continues to be the fuel in the tank,” with “strong field checks indicating the company could beat commercial cloud expectations by approximately 3%+.”

He reiterated an Outperform rating and $160 price target on the shares, arguing that it is still early innings for Azure’s momentum. Microsoft was up 0.3% to $138.63 in afternoon trading.

Looking ahead. Ives writes that the cloud business has positioned Microsoft well for 2020. The company “is poised to win the lion's share of the next phase of cloud deployments vs. Amazon.com (AMZN) and [Jeff] Bezos,” he says.

He anticipates that Azure’s momentum will continue into 2021, helped by the long-term shift to the cloud and Microsoft’s successful efforts to grab more of the enterprise pie from Amazon Web Services, the current leader.

Microsoft has endured recent volatility linked to the trade war relatively well, Ives says. More “investors are starting to appreciate how leveraged Redmond is to the transformational cloud trend set to play out over the coming years in this ‘cloud arms race,’ along with [Microsoft’s] unparalleled enterprise customer base,” he writes.

Write to Teresa Rivas at teresa.rivas@barrons.com
description: Wedbush says market-share gains for Azure can help the stock to keep rallying.
